title: How does the Means Test lines 22-24 (car), 32 (telecommunications), & 36 (fam violence) work? And is modifying expenses wise?
question: Below I list the problematic lines and the issues:
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Telecommunications law,Transportation law,Violent crime,Tax law
answers: If you are into the guts of the means test like this it probably means you have to do the long form version of the means test because you fail the presumption of abuse arises and you have to rebut it. You probably do not qualify for Chapter 7 due to your income and you have to do a Chapter 13. If you do a Chapter 13 hire a lawyer to do the means test for you and do not do it yourself. This is a mine field and the creditors and trustee will, spank you and kick you out of court for not getting it right. Spend about $500 on a retainer for a Chapter 13 lawyer and do it right the first time or dont do bankruptcy at all.

These questions are among the many reasons why bankruptcy is not a good do-it-yourself project. Attorneys invest a lot of time to understand how to deal with the means test, and it's unreasonable for you to expect them to simply give away their knowledge gratis in a forum like this one. You wouldn't care about the answers if you weren't above median income, and my belief is that above-median debtors can and should pay full fare for bankruptcy.

I am assuming you are using the Chapter 7 Means Test - #B22A -
22A: If over 6 yrs or 75K miles, add $200 per vehicle - but the maximum is 2 vehicles.
22B: If you claim you also use public transportation, check the box and insert the IRS standard, which is currently $182.00 for Los Angeles.
23/24: These are filled in only if you are financing your car(s). If you own them outright, then nothing is filled in here.
32: As stated in #32, you only include that portion that is for such items as pagers, call waiting, caller ID, special long distance, or internet service - but not any amounts for your basic home telephone or cell phone service. In other words, usually only the amount you pay for internet access plus any special fees for call waiting, etc.
36: This is a specialized deduction that only relates to costs incurred under the Family Violence Prevention and Services Act, such as if you were previously the victim of a violent crime.
The proper completion of the Means Test, and the proper claiming of exemptions to protect your assets is something that you really should have an attorney represent you in. Or, you should at least consult with a local attorney on these issues since you could cause yourself a lot of grief trying to do it on your own.
